Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or proof to support the assertion that the Zee News employee assaulted a doctor. The only evidence provided is the CCTV footage, but it is not clear whether it is genuine or if it actually shows a Zee News employee.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the person in the video is a Zee News employee without providing any concrete evidence or verification. It is based on the assumption made by the Twitter user and others who shared the video.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the video is not from India, as pointed out by several users. The video is actually an old footage from China showing an incident that occurred in 2018.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the severity of the situation by suggesting that the Zee News employee was refusing to get tested for COVID-19. There is no evidence or context provided in the claim to support this assertion.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement in the provided claim.
Falters at times: The claim falters in terms of accuracy and reliability by presenting an old video from China as a recent incident involving a Zee News employee. This raises questions about the credibility of the claim.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not provide any alternative explanations or consider other possibilities for the incident shown in the video. It jumps to the conclusion that it involves a Zee News employee without exploring other potential scenarios.
